Cédric Beust ♔ wrote:
> On 7/29/07, Ilja Preuss <it@...> wrote:
>>  Personally, I typically prefer the Just Create One pattern:
>>  http://butunclebob.com/ArticleS.UncleBob.SingletonVsJustCreateOne
> 
> This pattern looks quite inferior to what you can achieve with
> dependency injection.

In fact, it *is* a simple form of dependency injection - the injection 
is done by a hardcoded assembler (the "main method").

A DI framework certainly can give you more flexibility. I don't think 
that's always needed. Anyway, when it's needed, it's still an elaborate 
from of JCO, as far as I can tell.

> This approach also strongly couples the main() method with the
> implementation of the singleton you want to pass around, which is very
> bad.

Use your imagination. You can easily adapt the pattern so that it 
doesn't. I'd guess that most DI containers evolved that way.

> A framework like Guice gives you the power to solve all these problems
> while giving you a lot of control on the lifecycle of your objects and
> flexibility in your design.  It's odd that Rob doesn't even mention it
> in this article.

I'm not Uncle Bob, but I'd guess that his goal with the article was to 
show a simple alternative to the Singleton pattern, not to explore the 
whole solution space for the problem.

Cheers, Ilja
